author: Virginia Van Zanten
title: Decorating Lessons on the 35th Anniversary of The Official Preppy Handbook
text:
It’s the book that brought us the definitive guide to the old-boy network and boarding schools, taught mere Midwesterners to master the “Locust Valley Lockjaw,” and helped bring “go-to-hell” pants into the vernacular. And a surprising amount of The Official Preppy Handbook rings just as true today as it did when it was published 35 years ago this month, the absence of URLs in favor of lists of mail-order catalogs notwithstanding. One area in particular that has stood the test of time? Decor (including the supremely specific wedding registry guide). As it reads in the introduction: “Like everything else, Preppiness begins in the home.”
“There is only one look in Prep decorating: Not Decorated.” So begins the chapter on all things interior design. “Nothing is consciously coordinated, but everything works together through a successful marriage of utility and excellence. . . . If The Look must be pinned down, the look is English-American with a dash of seaside resort and women’s handicraft.” And, of course, one must not forget the all-important duck motif. “The duck is the most beloved of all totems. . . . And the less an object has to do with ducks, the more it cries out for duck adornment.” So, perhaps, 35 years later, it’s high time to take another look at this classic preppy decor. It’s not quite au courant, but that’s the point, isn’t it?
Above, from the circa-1980 pages (but shoppable in 2015), the 20 items to consider adding (judiciously) to the modern preppy home.
